name: Otitis Media (Acute): Antimicrobial Prescribing
citation: NICE, NG91: Otitis Media (Acute): Antimicrobial Prescribing, March 2022
rules: IF the child or young person is systemically very unwell OR has symptoms and signs of a more serious illness or condition OR has high risk of complications THEN Refer to hospital.

IF there is otorrhoea in any child or young person OR the child is under 2 years with infection in both ears THEN Offer regular doses of paracetamol or ibuprofen for pain, AND Consider no antibiotic or a back-up antibiotic prescription, AND Consider eardrops containing an anaesthetic and an analgesic for pain IF an immediate antibiotic is not given AND if there is no eardrum perforation or otorrhoea.

IF no antibiotic is given THEN Advise the parent or caregiver that antibiotics are not needed and to seek medical help if symptoms worsen rapidly or significantly, do not improve after 3 days, or the child becomes very unwell.

IF a back-up antibiotic prescription is given THEN Advise that the antibiotic is not needed immediately, to use the prescription if no improvement in 3 days or symptoms worsen, and to seek medical help if symptoms worsen rapidly or significantly, or the child becomes very unwell.
IF an immediate antibiotic prescription is given THEN Advise to seek medical help if symptoms worsen rapidly or significantly, or the child becomes very unwell.

Reassess at any time if symptoms worsen rapidly or significantly, taking into account other possible diagnoses, any symptoms or signs suggesting a more serious illness or condition, and previous antibiotic use which may lead to resistant organisms.
Advise that acute otitis media lasts about 3 days but can last up to 1 week.
